Understanding Links

A link is a connection between two folders, two items, or a folder and an item. Creating links can increase the efficiency with which you work. For example, when you review a file, if the change requests that affect that file have been linked to it, you can review the change requests without selecting the Change Request tab. You simply select the file, then click the Link tab from the lower pane, and double-click the appropriate link to see its properties.

In addition, linking files to change requests allows them to be marked as fixed when you check in the corresponding files. Also, if you link each set of files to the requirements document that they fulfill, you can easily refer to or update that document.

A link does not provide a connection to a single share (or reference), but to all related shares and branches of an item. Links are not affected by any item operations, such as branching, moving, sharing, etc.

By default, a link connects the tip revisions of the linked pair. For further information, see Creating Links.
